title: River Raisin National Battlefield Park: NPS Centennial
body: Explore This Park    Get Involved     NPS Centennial            NPS Centennial         Gerald Maitland accepting a reward for his volunteer service from River Raisin NBPF executive director Terry Beamsley NPS Staff  In honor of the National Park Service Centennial V.I.P Volunteer Gerald Maitland wrote a poem about the NPS Anniversary. Gerald is a sixth grader in Pioneers Homeschool Co-op.  His poem received first place out of more than a thousand entries!   Nature should be for everyone All our parks are not just for fun They teach us lessons of the past I am sure you will be flabbergast Our history brings you back in time Network of rangers come rain or shine A junior ranger can earn a badge Learning extra sometimes gives a patch   Preserved places are great for a hike Allowing many people to bike Relax in comfort in a camper Kids will like tenting and won't hamper States rejoice with park units abound   Stewardship will need to be passed down Education is there and all around Recreation can also be found Volunteers do help in every way In making inspirational days Celebrate the centennial mark Each person needs to protect our parks        The National Park Service turns 100 on August 25, 2016. As we lead up to the centennial, we invite you to participate in Find Your Park Experiences to learn, discover, be inspired, or simply have fun in national parks. Find Your Park Experiences offer unique opportunities to explore national parks both in person and online. Check out the experiences in this park or search all experiences to identify an opportunity that matches your interests. You can also share your national park story at FindYourPark.com. A Call to Action remains the foundation for our 2016 centennial preparations. It is the National Park Service's blueprint for the future, outlining the innovative work we want to accomplish. River Raisin National Battlefield Park is a big part of this effort. Take a look at what we're doing and get involved!   Experiences      A Battlefield and A Beach?  That’s right, at the River Raisin National Battlefield Park there is something for everyone!  Whether you are a history buff, hiker, biker, or whether you are into camping, swimming, boating, kayaking, fishing, wildlife watching, or birding,we have it all within your reach! Within an hour drive, or by connecting trails, you can experience it all at the River Raisin National Battlefield Park, William C. Sterling State Park, and the Detroit River International Wildlife Refuge Read more   Find Artifacts From the Battle of the River Raisin!  “Where it Happened on the Geocache Trail” will take you through a journey on the sacred grounds of the Battlefield where you will discover what happened during the Battle over 200 years ago! A geocache is a hidden treasure that you locate by using a GPS device.  With our activity you do not take anything however.  You will search for ten battle artifacts using a GPS unit that the park provides.  You can also do the Footprints of the Geocache Trail and find animal tracks. Read more   Kayak Through History  In 2014 the Park offered “The Art of Kayaking” on the River Raisin and Huron River for the first time!  The program is continuing through the Centennial.  Visitors are taught  to kayak while learning the importance of water ways in history.  Visitors participating at the Huron River are being offered the first public tours of the Historic Hulls Trace!  Truly a unique opportunity to “Find Your Park” and get up close and personal with a 200 year old tangible remnant of history. Read more   Ticket to Float  The Ticket to Float Urban Youth Outdoor Kayak Explorer Program engages youth in kayaking and learning about preservation of our Nations Natural and Cultural Resources during a full day field trip experience at River Raisin National Battlefield Park. In 2015 the program reached over 1200 youth.  The Park is looking forward to continuing the program through the Centennial. Check out our videos to learn about the program, click on the slider button to see each video. Read more      Call to Action Projects      Almost Time to Smell the Roses!  The National Park Service and Tournament of Roses Association are partnering to kick off the centennial with the 2016 Rose Parade in Pasadena, California.
